user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of make_blocking:
```c
static void
make_blocking (MHD_socket fd)
{
#if defined(MHD_POSIX_SOCKETS)
  int flags;

  flags = fcntl (fd, F_GETFL);
  if (-1 == flags)
    abort ();
  if ((flags & ~O_NONBLOCK) != flags)
    if (-1 == fcntl (fd, F_SETFL, flags & ~O_NONBLOCK))
      abort ();
#elif defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS)
  unsigned long flags = 0;

  if (0 != ioctlsocket (fd, (int) FIONBIO, &flags))
    abort ();
#endif /* MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS */
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#elif defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS)
  unsigned long flags = 0;

  if (0 != ioctlsocket (fd, (int) FIONBIO, &flags))
    abort ();
#endif /* MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS */
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The winsock branch is conditionally compiled via #elif defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS); by itself this is not unreachable. This is not a Rule 2.1 violation unless the project configuration never defines MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS for any build (i.e. the Winsock branch can never be compiled or executed in any delivered build). In that specific case (no build of the project ever defines MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS) the code would be unreachable across the project and thus would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1.
